titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I walked this morning, and again before dinner, notwithstanding my hoarseness, and a sprained foot. I am extremely reluctant at abandoning my new regimen, even for a few days; but shall be compelled to do it— I had morning visits from Mr Montreal, and Mr Hollins— Dr Galloway was here in the Evening— I began the twelfth Oration of Isocrates. The Panathenaic—which he says he commenced writing at the age of ninety-four— In the Evening I read the Sermons 11 and 12. Vol. 2. of the English Preacher—the former on Religious Retirement, by Bishop Atterbury, the best I have yet met with in this Collection— The latter is Butler’s character of Balaam, which I have read more than once before— The greatest merit of this Sermon, is the sagacity of analysis in explaining and unfolding the mysterious Scripture accounts of this personage—and the ingenuity of application in bringing it home to the preacher’s auditory— Immediately before going to bed this Night, I tried the experiment of a warm bath.

2. My warm bath was not successful, and my cold was this day more troublesome than it has yet been. I was obliged to give up my walk before breakfast, and almost for the day— I had a morning visit from the Chevalier de Bray; and one from Mr Patterson— I rode out with Charles, paid a visit to Mr Jouffroy, Prussian Chargé d’Affairs, since Baron Schladen went away. Attempted a walk on the quay; but was immediately driven by the weather to the Carriage again— Mr Fisher dined with us and Mr Harris paid us an Evening visit— I was quite unwell, and excessively hoarse— I read the remainder of the Panathenaic, and the fragment against the Sophists— The Panathenaic was finished when the author was ninety seven, and bears the marks of his age— In the fragment he contends like Socrates that virtue cannot be taught.

3. After a hot foot-bath last Night, and a copious draught of elder-flower tea, repeated this morning, I kept my bed untill eleven O’Clock, and did not go out of the house the whole day— The confinement was very irksome, but my cold was better this Evening, and my hoarseness some what diminished— I resigned the day almost entirely to idleness, but read in the Evening a few pages in the third volume of the Itineraire—respecting the topography of the Battles in Tasso’s Jerusalem delivered; which he says is remarkably correct, and which he took pains one day to spend five hours, in ascertaining, by personal inspection with the Book in his hand— We had Evening visits from Mr Plummer, and the Chevalier de Longuerue.

4. I rose this morning just at the dawn of day, that is, about 8 O’Clock, and the weather being mild and fine, after sun-rise took a walk before breakfast— On returning home, as I pass’d before the Corner of the Palace, I saw the Emperor come out from his apartments, mount his horse, and go round, followed by five Officers his Aid de Camps, and enter the inner Court of the Palace, where he holds almost Every Morning a private review of the Guards— I met Nelson walking; who looked and complained of being very unwell— I had a morning visit from General Watzdorf, whose conversation was pleasant; mine to him was not prudent. I know not whether the Vanity of other men, draws upon them such frequent self-reproach and mortification as mine does upon me; but my reflections upon my own indiscretions cost me many uneasy hours, which seldom produce amendment— General Watzdorf is a man of perhaps fifty-five—grave, sentimental, polite and somewhat formal— Very punctilious in giving the title of Excellency to his Colleagues, though it is entirely out of use in the familiar conversation of all the rest, and sounds to me so ridiculous, that I cannot prevail upon myself even to return it to him in his own way— The General is a cool, judicious man, sometimes much addicted to yawning in Company, and occasionally to dose— A good latin Scholar—occasionally quoting Horace; but having no keen relish for literature of any kind. He attends the Emperor on Sundays at the parade, by his own desire, where his horse trots while all the rest of the Cavalcade are upon the Canter— The General is intimate with the Grand-Marshal Count Tolstoy, and visits at Mr Gourieff’s and Princess Dolgorucky’s— He gets like Baron Blome such information as is to be obtained from this Company, very quick and very correctly— That is to say, every thing that the Government here chuse they should know— Of the secret information he has not such good sources— On the whole he is a man much like his Sovereign the king of Saxony— He lives here without his family, and in an unassuming and economical style. He was at the battle of Wagram, and had been in the military Career, untill his Mission to this Country— I walked again before dinner, and met young Baron Löwenstern; with whom I walked— He accompanied the Chevalier de Bray, and Madame on their Journey to Italy— Dr: Galloway was here this Evening— I read the Oration of Isocrates for the Plataeans, and finished the third Book of Manilius— In the Evening I read the Itinéraire— The Oration, was to implore the protection of the Athenians against the Thebans— It characterises the manners of that Age and Country— Manilius continues a profound and incomprehensible Astrologer— This book laboriously prepares the student of the Stars, for the Art of drawing the horoscope.— As it depends on the state of the Zodiac, he gives rules for ascertaining the time and period of the rising and setting of every sign, throughout the year— Chateaubriand was dubb’d by the Guardian Father of the Holy Land, a knight of the holy sepulchre—then left Jerusalem and went to Egypt— He saw the pyramids only at a distance— The Nile being too high for him to go by land, and too low to go by Water— He gives an account of five French Soldiers, relicts of the army of Bonaparte, whom he found as Mammeluke chiefs at Cairo. The principal of them was Abdallah, the son of a Shoemaker at Toulouse— But the author takes great pride in them as Frenchmen— He found too a rich turkish merchant, who knew Son cher Atala, et sa chere Réné— It almost reconciled him to the Turks.

5. Rose before six, and resumed the ordinary walk, which I had commenced the custom of taking before breakfast— The weather has been so long moderate that the river has the appearance of threatening to break up, and there is no snow on the ground; but it is extremely damp and dark, and there can scarcely be said to be any daylight, throughout the 24 hours— I had morning visits from Messrs: Patterson and Hollins, Harris, Saltus and Fisher— Mr Saltus is immediately going to Riga— Madame de Betancourt, and her two daughters spent part of the Evening here. I read the Oration of Isocrates on the permutation, or Exchange of Estates— This is in his own Cause. He says it was written when he was eighty-four year old— There is no lack of egotism in this orator’s discourses— This Oration is entirely about himself, and produces as proofs of his patriotism long extracts from three of the former Orations— Began the fourth Book of Manilius— It is a beautiful poetical exordium about Fate— And then it contains further rules concerning the influence of the Celestial sign upon human destinies— In the Evening I finished the Itinèraire, which I have read with much pleasure— It finishes with the Account of the Author’s Voyage from Egypt to Tunis, and an account of antient Carthage, and its History— There is perhaps too much of this, and of extracts from antient Historians in the Book; but altogether I have found it entertaining— From Tunis, he went to Spain in an American Schooner— Of Spain he says but a few words;
and concludes the narrative at Bayonne. He announces his intention if he should enjoy in future a tranquility which he has never had, to raise in Silence a Monument that may do honour to his Country; but observes he has at all Events written enough if his name is to last; and too much if not. In this last Volume he pays two or three Compliments to Volney’s travels— So that the Silence I had before observed was not so significant as I had thought.

6. Rose between eight and nine this morning— This irregularity proves the difficulty which I shall experience in settling a steady rising hour— I now attribute the varieties which continually occur to the severe Cold, under which I am still labouring— I took however my six miles walk, before Breakfast— As I was returning I met Mr Bezerra, upon the Square— He told me the Turkish Peace was to be signed the 15th.— I had a morning visit from Mr Montreal; and in the Evening, we had visits from Madam Bezerra, and Captain Guédiz— I read the 16th: Oration of Isocrates—on the Chariot Horses— It is in the person of a Son of Alcibiades, upon a suit of Tisias to recover the horses, as having been extorted from him by Alcibiades— The Son, (whose name does not appear in the Speech) says that his father bought the horses of the Argives; and that this suit was brought against him, only to increase the odium against his father who had been banished, and had perished— The whole Oration is a defence of the Character of Alcibiades.— It seems to be an address to the People, and against a public accusation— But why was the Cause tried before the people? and what is meant by the pretence that Alcibiades had extorted the horses?— The English Translator tells us nothing about this. The Oration is peculiarly interesting, as it exhibits a man obviously innocent, struggling against the oppression of popular Odium brought upon him by his father; yet exerting his best faculties to extricate his fathers fame, from that Odium— It contains many particulars about Alcibiades, and sets out with filial affection and piety all the fair parts of his character— I also finished reading the fourth Book of Manilius which contains an account of the influence of each sign of the Zodiac, upon the character of those born under it, and also upon the different parts of the Earth— There is a tolerably minute geographical description of the world then known— But as none of the Signs are reserved for the superintendence of the Terrae incognitae, the American Hemisphere has no patrons or foes among the Constellations— In the Evening I read a little in the Appendix to the Itinéraire, and began d’Anville’s dissertation upon antient Jerusalem.— This was the festival of St Catherine— A day upon which it has been customary for a diplomatic Circle to be held at Court— This day however there was none.

7. I was up before six this morning, but waited untill daylight to take my Morning walk— I paid visits to the French Ambassador, to Count St: Julien, and to Count Bussche; but found neither of them at home— Walked again before dinner— In the Evening I went to the public baths, and took a hot water-bath, with a Russian vapour Bath— I find myself hardly able to go through this kind of bath, and I neither endured the fustigation nor the pouring hot water on the Stove to increase the heat. Mr Fisher dined with us, and pass’d the Evening with the Ladies— Read the 17th: Oration of Isocrates, called the Banker—a Question upon a deposit—in a cause altogether judicial— The name of the person for whom it was delivered does not appear— He lays the greatest stress of his argument upon the Banker’s refusal to let a slave be tortured for Evidence—and asserts as a matter generally admitted that this species of evidence was better than any other—

8. The effect of the hot-bath which I took last Night was so violent, that I pass’d the whole Night without sleep; and almost in a continual profuse perspiration; with a high fever— I did not rise untill after nine this morning; and the heat had not even then entirely pass’d off— I took a ride in the afternoon before dinner with Mrs: Adams— We had Evening visits from Mrs: Bentzon, and from Mr Harris— I head the 18th: Oration of Isocrates; against Callimachus— For whom it was written does not appear. But Callimachus had accused him of having extorted money from him— The Cause therefore is private and judicial— Read also the 13th: 14th. & 15th. Sermons Vol. 2. of the English preacher— On the pleasures of Religion— Religious Gratitude— and Haman and Mordecai— I attempted to write in the Evening, but was so weary and drowsy that I was obliged to abstain.

9. After a long Night’s repose, I rose this morning about 8 O’Clock; and gave this day also to the cure of my Cold— I had morning visits from Mr: Dana who has arrived lately from Archangel; and from Mr Fisher with Mr Ducoster— Evening visits from Mr Hollins and Mr Patterson— Mrs Adams, who rode out this morning in the Sleigh, was very suddenly seized in the Evening with a violent fever, and was obliged to leave the company and take to her bed— I walked only once this day, and that was between 2 and 4. in the afternoon. I first met General Pardo,
who told me that from a particular source of information that he had, he doubted whether the Peace with Turkey would come to a conclusion— Afterwards I met the Emperor on the Fontanka; who on meeting me said— Monsieur Adams, j’ai l’honneur de vous présenter mes respects—a mode of salutation which proved him to be in good humour and Spirits.— He proceeded as usual to remark upon the weather—that this day it was fine; but that for some time past it had been like the climate of Portugal at this Season— And then said he we have two Comets at once— I said I had seen some such intimation in the Newspapers; but had not seen the second Comet— Oh! that, said he is certain c’est positif— But furthermore, I hear that one of the fixed Stars, namely Sirius, has sunk one degree in the firmament— But for this I will give you my authority— C’est Monsieur l’Ambassadeur de France.— I said this was extraordinary news indeed— C’est un bouleversement general du Ciel— said he— But, said I, as it is generally understood that one Comet portends great disasters, it is to be hoped that two, must signify some great happiness to the world— Or at least, said he, that their mischief will operate mutually against each other, and by reciprocal counteraction destroy the evil efficacy of both— I congratulated His Majesty, upon his happy solution of the portentous knot— He laughed and said, il y a moyen d’expliquer toutes ces choses là— I read this morning the 19th: Oration of Isocrates— The Æginetic— A Cause about a Will, and an inheritance—much resembling the Speeches of Isaeus, as translated by Sir William Jones— This is the case of a devisee taking the Estate, from the heiress at Law— In the Evening I continued reading d’Anville’s Dissertation upon antient Jerusalem, in the Appendix to Chateaubriand’s Itinéraire; but did not finish it, owing to the interruption of our Evening visitors.

10. Mrs Adams was excessively ill the whole Night— Catherine came and knocked at my door to rouse me, but I slept so sound that I did not hear her— I rose about seven and after reading an hour took my morning walk— It was at breakfast after my return that I learnt how ill my wife had been— She was rather better, but still very unwell the whole of this day— She has what the Doctor calls the weed fever, and one breast much inflamed. Dr. Galloway was here this morning, and again in the Evening— I walked after Breakfast, about an hour, with Charles. Finished reading Dinsdale’s Isocrates— The 20th: and 21st: Orations are both very short— That against Lochites is for what we should call Assault and Battery— The Cause without a witness, is for the recovery of a deposit; of which there was no Evidence.— The action would not be sustainable in any modern judicial Courts— The arguments are very ingenious, but founded solely upon an estimate of probabilities— There are nine Epistles—written to Philip and Alexander of Macedon, and some others— In one of them the author seems to think the only difference between an Epistle and an Oration consists in their length— I have now read all that is left of Isocrates, though in so wretched a translation, that it can give scarcely any idea of the Orator— He is full of egotism—and of morality. There are Orations of all the three Classes— Deliberative, Judicial and Demonstrative— Some of them are apparently fragments— The Exordium when there is one, is always upon one topic, the Orator himself— One of the Orations only seems to be regularly composed, with the formal partitions— They are all in the calm and unimpassioned manner— And with a very moderate use of imagery— In the Evening I finished reading the Appendix to the Itinéraire; which concludes with a Memoir of Questions concerning Tunis and their Answers— Mr Ingraham paid us a visit this Evening; but was not received, Mrs Adams being too unwell to see any Company.

11. Mrs Adams though much better the first part of this day was quite unwell again this Evening— The day pass’d entirely without visitors. I walked the round before breakfast, and again about an hour before dinner— I began reading the Abbé Augier’s translation of Demosthenes and Eschines— The first Volume consists altogether of preliminary discourses, and preparatory information.— I read only a few pages of the Discours preliminaire— He defines oratorical eloquence, the Art of producing immediate persuasion to action or decision, by discourse— He confines it therefore to the Deliberative, and Judicial kinds; excluding the Demonstrative— I find by some pencil marks that I had read this Discourse before; but I had no recollection of its Contents— A mortifying proof of the infirmity of my Memory— In the Evening I read the fifth and last Book of Manilius—and part of the Translation of Cicero’s Translation from Aratus— Manilius is incomplete— But the fifth book is altogether employed in describing the characters of men, as born at the rising of the respective Constellations—

12. Rose before six, this Morning, and walked before Breakfast— Morning visits from Mr Montréal, Mr Harris and Mr Hollins, who is going to France, but who has changed his intended way thither— Instead of going through Moscow, Vienna, and Strasburg he now proposes to go direct by the way of Mayence— I went out with the Sledge, and took Charles with me— Called at Klosterman’s, and Rospini’s bookseller’s shops to enquire for a Manilius, but without success. I wrote in the Evening; for in spite of all the pains I have taken, I find it still impracticable to write by Daylight.— Sophie was married last Evening.

13. I continue to rise about six in the morning and to walk before breakfast, though my health is yet disordered— I have now a severe Cold in the head which is very troublesome— After breakfast I attended an auction of Books, but without making any purchase— The Chevalier and Madam Bezerra, and Mr Harris paid us evening visits. I finished reading the Abbé Auger’s Discours Préliminaire; which contains a number of good observations—on Eloquence in general; and on those of Greece, Rome and France in particular— On Demosthenes, Eschines and Cicero; with the opinions of Dionysius, Longinus, Quinctilian and Cicero concerning them— On the principles of translation; and on the manner in which his translation was made—together with some good advice to young Students of Oratory— The good Abbe intimates that to translate any antient writer a man must have just the same kind of Genius as the original— He says he tried to be as much like Demosthenes as he could; but there is yet a difference perceptible between them— He breaks his discourse too much and too often by long Notes, which is a great fault in composition— The antients never wrote notes upon their own works; and in general they are faults in the writing of the Moderns— All the Abbé’s Notes for instance should have been interwoven into the Discourse— A note is nothing but a long parenthesis— In poetry or history they may be used by way of explanation, or reference to authorities— But from didactic treatises and oratorical works they should generally be excluded— In the Evening I finished reading the Arataea of Cicero, as translated by Pingré, after the Manilius— But they are much less amusing.

14. My walk before breakfast has become a habit which I so seldom intermit that I shall no longer notice it daily. If I have health, I shall continue the practice regularly; and the intermissions will be the exceptions— The change in my manner of living, with which I commenced it, has not yet corresponded with my wishes and hopes on undertaking it— But my intention is to persevere in it, and my hopes are still as sangwine as at the first— I attended again the auction of Books, and made a few purchases.— Began reading Auger’s Précis Historique, to facilitate the understanding of Demosthenes and Eschines— It relates to the History and Constitution of the Grecian States.— To the Government, festivals and computation of time among the Athenians—their collective character, and that of the Romans—and the History and character of Philip of Macedon.— I was engaged much of the morning in the regulation of my monthly household accounts, an object which takes no small portion of my time and attention. Dined with the French Ambassador— A company of twenty-two or twenty-three persons,—chiefly the foreign Ministers— The Ambassador plays at Tennis, by way of exercise, and recommended it to me— But I do not understand it, and think it too late to begin to learn— I believe however that the exercise of walking, taken alone, without any other is not sufficient for health, and I have not esteemed as I ought the exercises of the body which required strong exertion— In the education of my children, I hope to attend to it— The dinner at the Ambassadors was short— Count Ozarowski, and the two Kablukoffs were there— One of them lately arrived from Paris as a Courier— In the Evening I paid a visit to the Chevalier Bezerra— Madam Colombi, Don Francisco and Mr Zea came in while I was there— I also visited at Mr Krehmer’s, but they were not at home— Mr Fisher and Mr Ingraham paid us Evening visits.

15. There was no general parade this morning; but when I pass’d by the corner of the Palace the Emperor’s horses were waiting for him at his private door. I had a long morning visit from Count Bussche, and was very unwillingly engaged again most of the hours of day, in the settlement of my accounts— Wrote nothing— Not even the Journal of yesterday— Finished reading Auger’s Précis Historique—his list of the tribes and Bourgs of Athens, and began his Treatise upon the Jurisdiction and Laws of Athens— This last is not so clear and precise as I should wish— It does not give a very distinct idea of the powers and duties of the several magistrates and judges, nor of the authority of the people.— Mr Fisher and Mr Ingraham dined, and spent part of the Evening with us. I read the Sermons 1. and 2. Vol 4. of the English Preacher— On the example of Jesus in doing good— And on Nathan’s reproof to David— I was so unwell with my Cold in the Evening that I could not read in the Horae Paulinae— Retired before 10. to bed— And thus another day was almost wholly withdrawn from the employments to which I meant to devote it— There is a difficulty in the Execution of all Resolutions requiring perseverance, upon which we do not calculate before hand— I am afraid it resolves itself into a characteristic deficiency in the very quality of perseverance— It sometimes seems to me, as if it was sufficient for me to resolve upon any thing to fail in its accomplishment.

16. Last evening at nine O’Clock was the new moon, and just at that time the weather changed, as the Emperor had prophesied— It has now become much colder— Mr W. G. Smith called on me this forenoon, and informed me that he should be ready to go next Sunday. He goes to England and perhaps to America— I attended the auction, and purchased again a few Books— Catherine spent the Evening abroad—with Mrs Bentzon. I finished reading Auger’s Dissertation upon the Laws and Jurisdiction of Athens. In the Evening read only some English Newspapers sent me by Mr Krehmer— I took a hot foot-bath before going to bed— My Cold continues without abatement.

17. Mr Fisher called upon me this morning, with a Mr Williams of New-York, lately arrived from Archangel. Their visit made me about ten minutes too late at the auction for the books I wished to purchase. Dined with Mrs Adams and Catherine at Count Romanzoff’s. It was a dinner to the Princess Amelia of Baden, the Empress’s Sister, and there were twelve or thirteen ladies present—among whom were Madame Bezerra and Madame de Bray, with Miss Lise Löwenstern— It was the first time I had dined at the Count’s with Ladies— I led in Countess Kotschubey and was seated between her and Madame de Bray.— I had some Conversation with the Countess who appears to be a woman of sense and reflection; very much attached to her Country— None of the unmarried Ministers were there, but the Ambassador with the Chevalier de Longuerue, and Count St. Julien with Mr Lebzeltern. Prince Lubomirski was there; and told me that he had not had an opportunity to deliver the letters I had given him; having concluded to return from England here— We came home between 7 and 8 in the Evening— Catherine went to Madam Colombi’s— Mr W. G. Smith was here part of the Evening— I read the Geographical table and the analysis of Contents at the close of Auger’s introductory Volume— With the preliminary remarks at the beginning of the second— And the translation of the first Philippic.

18. Morning visits from Mr Fisher— Mr Patterson and Mr W. G. Smith— It was a Holiday—the festival of St: Nicholas— I dined with Mr Fisher and a Company of twenty Americans— I came home very early this Evening; with a new cold and wounded heels, to arrest my morning walks— I read the three Olynthiac’s in Auger’s translation— He calls them the second, third and fourth philippic— He follows a different arrangement from that of the Editors of Demosthenes, but I know not which is the most correct— I am much pleased with Auger’s Translation; but I cannot bring myself to prefer Demosthenes as an Orator to Cicero— There is so much uniformity, and so little compass in the arguments of the philippics—such continual recurrence of the same thoughts, and often of the same expressions—the complaints against the Athenians, and the charges against Philip may be summed up in so very few words; there is so much littleness in the measures proposed by the Orator, independent of their ill-success—the discourses are so dry—so destitute of all liveliness of wit or brilliancy of imagination, as well as of all pathetic sentiment that I cannot help feeling the want in them of that charm so profusely lavished in the Eloquence of Cicero— I do not always see in the Philippics, what is the real question in deliberation.—and when you do see it, how is it possible to fancy the fate of the world depending upon the doubt whether the Athenians shall raise two thousand men of infantry, two hundred of Cavalry, and send them out with ten gallies, and levy 50,000 dollars to maintain them— The measures of Demosthenes never reach beyond this— The close logic, the ardent and sublime sentiment, the disinterested patriotism, and the holy indignation against the usurping tyrant Philip, I admire as much as Fenelon— I wrote this day part of a letter, and before ten at Night retired unwell to bed.

19. I was prevented from taking my walk this morning, and indeed was confined to the house the whole day by the wounds in my feet; by a return of my Cold, and by a fall of Snow— Had a morning visit from Mr Harris— In the Evening the Ladies went to the Theatre— I read the 5th: 6th. and 7th: Philippics in Auger’s Translation—the fifth hardly harmonizes with the rest— It is on the question whether the Athenians shall recognize the admission of Philip as a member of the amphictyonic Council—the Orator advises acquiescence, to avoid the danger of a general War against Athens, which he thinks not to be hazarded for a mere shadow at Delphi— The sixth, or second of the four Philippics exclusively so called, is one of those which do not indicate the question in debate— It is a general invective against Philip— Auger’s Summary says it was to urge an alliance with Sparta against him— It appears rather to be an argument for an impeachment of those who had advised the Peace with Philip; and especially one man (they, he says, know who) and Auger says it was Eschines.— In this Oration is the fine repetition of what Demosthenes had said to the Messenians—advising them to Distrust, as a protection to their liberties— Here too he urges the natural hatred
of kings for Republics; and here he speaks of himself as a Water-drinker— Auger says that Philip on reading this Oration said, I should have voted for a Declaration of War against myself and for appointing Demosthenes the General— The seventh, is upon the Halonesus, and several other points mentioned in a letter from Philip to the Athenians, which however has not been preserved. This Oration is thought spurious, and Auger says is attributed to Hegesippus— One reason for rejecting it is that he says, if his hearers have their brains in their heads and not in their heels they will totally ruin Philip’s partizans among themselves— There is also a bitter, sarcastic, but by no means delicate irony too in many passages of this Oration, which are not in the manner of the great Orator; whose gravity is inflexible— The reasoning in it is rather captious than solid; and there is none of that exalted sentiment, so glorious in Demosthenes— I still wrote very little.— The child Louisa’s first tooth came through this Night.

20. Resumed my usual walk before breakfast, although my feet are not entirely healed— I received the Courier’s Passport for Mr Smith, and gave it to him, when he called— In my second walk, before dinner I met the Emperor, who asked me if it was now cold enough for me— I answered him, very reasonably cold, though I had heard that the Comet had been warming us for some Months— He said that opinion would not answer now—(the thermometer was at about 14 of Fahrenheit) I asked him if His Majesty had any news from the fixed Stars?— He laughed, and said, none, since the information given him by the French Ambassador,—who had told him that Some astronomer had announced the fall of Sirius, one degree— But General Pardo, who was himself a learned Astronomer had told him that even if the fact were so, it could not have been discovered here, because the fixed Stars have no parallax, and the variation of a degree in the position of them would not be perceptible to us— He was not Astronomer enough to know whether this was correct— I said, nor I— But I had a prepossession against making a wandering Star of Sirius— His movements had hither been so long regular, as well as the whole Government of the Heavenly bodies, that I did not readily credit their now beginning to change their character.— He said he believed the best way was to let the Heavens take their course, without meddling with their Management— In the Evening Mrs Adams and Catherine went out and paid several visits— I read the Port-Folio—a new Volume, given me by Mr Roberts— I had read in the Morning the 8th: and ninth Philippics. They are principally devoted to the defence of Diopithes an Athenian General, who to maintain his unpaid troops had committed some unauthorized hostilities upon Philip’s territories— Auger thinks the 9th: the finest of all the Philippics—

21. I was at Sun-rise this morning, at the spot on the Quay, opposite the Winter Palace, where I have observed the rising Sun, at the Solstices— But the Sun was not visible—nor has been at Sunrise, for weeks. Morning visit from Mr Montreal; and in the Evening from Chevalier Bezerra, who came to bring the dispatches to be forwarded by Mr Smith. I wrote to my Mother, a letter to send by the same occasion. Read the tenth Philippic, which is little more than a repetition of the eighth superadding a violent invective against Aristodemus, at the close— I cannot believe that these Philippics were all delivered as they are now published— The repetition of whole pages in the same identical words, twice or three times over, at assemblies held within one or two years of each other, is neither consonant to the perfection of the Orators compositions—the greatness of his powers, nor the fastidious delicacy of an Athenian Audience— But they give rise to another scruple in my mind— Is it an indication of perfect compositions, that whole pages may be transported from one discourse to another, and be equally suitable for either.— Blair says that Demosthenes never recurred to the loci communes— But the usurpations of Philip, are the perpetual common place of all the Philippics, and you scarcely ever can discover the precise object of the deliberation on any one of the specific occasions of the discourses— In the tenth Philippic he argues in favour of the theatrical distributions, which in the third and fourth he had urged to have appropriated to maintain the troops— A remarkable example of compliance with popular prejudices and passions— Philip’s letter to the Senate and people of Athens is well written— With much moderation and dignity of expression—and with provoking coolness— He details all his causes of complaint against them; and in many particulars he appears to have reason and justice on his side— In all great human controversies the better side may be liable to the reproach of subordinate wrongs, more than their adversary. The Athenians were not altogether blameless in their proceedings towards Philip— But their faults were all of petty extent, and in the nature of defence— Philip’s wrong was enormous; it was the design of subjugating to himself all Greece— He winds his web round them like a spider round a fly— When I read those noble sentiments of Demosthenes, in which he compares the fortune of Athens with that of Philip, and prefers it upon the principle that truth and Justice, must be favoured by Heaven, when he contends that success and prosperity founded on fraud and treachery must be short-lived, I cannot avoid a feeling of sorrow, that these maxims were not sanctioned by the Event— That the triumph of fraud and treachery was complete, and that liberty sunk under the Genius and Industry of the tyrant— I remark as an item in estimating the oratorical powers of Demosthenes, that there is nothing like learning in his Orations— There is nothing that discovers a cultivated mind— There is little philosophy—
no indulgence to the imagination— No wit or humour— No attempt at ridicule; he is sufficiently figurative but all his figures are taken from familiar objects. His eloquence is characteristic of democracy as that of Cicero is to Aristocracy. It is as the Doric to the Corinthian Pillar.

22. Mr W. G. Smith came and took my letters and dispatches for America, and for London; and left the City about five O’Clock this afternoon— Mr Plummer came to inform me that Mr George Thorndike who has been several months unwell, was taken last Night so extremely ill, that it was doubtful whether he would survive this day.— Mr Harris spent the Evening with us— So much of the day was thus employed, that I read only the eleventh and last of the Philippics— Or the Oration upon Philip’s letter— And part of the Oration upon the Government of the Republic— The Philippic is short and full of repetitions; discussing none of the particulars of Philip’s letter, but considering it as a declaration of War, and urging the People to active exertion in maintaining it— The Oration upon the Government, is said to have been concerning the distribution of the War, or theatrical funds. There is not more than one page relative to that subject— The rest is miscellaneous and declamatory—proposing another meeting of the People, to reform the Government and correct the abuses of the Administration.— In the Evening I read two Sermons in the English preacher Vol. 4. on the Fear of Man; and on the reasonableness and Advantages of Public Worship— I could not even read a few pages of Paley— Nor write one line according to my intentions.— I finished reading the German Old Testament, and began the Apocrypha.

23. Mr P. O David a Citizen of the United States, though a native of France came for a Passport, which I gave him— He is going to Prussia and to Sweden, there to embark for America.— Mr Montréal came and shewed me a letter he had received from France, respecting the Radius a vessel of Mr W. Gray’s taken by a French privateer into Copenhagen and condemned at Paris— Mr Plummer came to inform me that Mr George Thorndike died this morning at eleven O’Clock, and to take advice of me respecting his funeral. Mr Dana and he, who propose to take the management of it, intend to pursue the same course as that taken at Mr Blodget’s death; the expence of which he says amounted to about 1500 Rubles.— They think to have the funeral on Thursday or Friday— I received a visit of introduction from Count Frohberg Montjoye the new Minister of Würtemberg, with whom came Count Schenk his Predecessor now recalled— From the Department of the Ceremonies, I received the Notice for the Court to-morrow, and the invitation to the Ladies and to me, for the Ball to be given by the Empress-Mother in the Evening— Madame Colombi paid a morning visit to the Ladies. I called on Mr Hynam to enquire whether he had yet ascertained with precision the proportion between the English and Russian weights— But he had not— Met in my walk before dinner the Chevalier Bezerra, who begins to doubt of the Turkish Peace— In the Evening we had visits from Messrs: Patterson, Hollins and Woodward.— I finished reading the Oration upon the Government of the Republic, and read those, upon the Classes, and for the Megalopolitans.— They are all said to have been delivered before any of the Philippics. That upon the Classes, relates to the designs of Artaxerxes, king of Persia, upon Greece, and against declaring War— That for the people of Megalopolis is founded upon the principle of preserving the balance of power, between the Thebans and Lacedemonians— They are in a more temperate style than the Philippics, but not inferior to them for closeness and subtlety of argument.

24. The Emperor Alexander’s birth day. There was a parade in the morning; but as there was a steady fall of Snow, I did not go out. Employed the hours before Sun-rise in writing and reading— Proceeding with Auger’s Demosthenes, I read the Orations, for the liberty of the Rhodians and on the Treaty of Alexander—also several of the Exordiums— The Oration for the Rhodians is among the best. But there is some inconsistency with himself in the principles of political morality that he lays down in it. That on the Treaty of Alexander, is allowed to be spurious. The style is not that of Demosthenes— There is nothing of his magnanimity of Sentiment in it; and the invective unlike his against Philip is coarse and heavy— Some of the Exordiums are the same that appear at the beginning of the Orations— It appears that Demosthenes was accustomed to have an assortment of Exordium’s on hand—ready to be tacked to any harangue for which there might be a sudden occasion— They are short, and couched in such general expressions as may apply equally well to any subject of discourse— He seems to have considered an exordium, as we look upon a prologue to a Play—as entirely distinct from the discourse itself— Cicero followed the same practice for his philosophical Treatises.— The Court was announced as usual, for Noon— I went a little before one; entering at the Hermitage as had been requested— The Imperial family were already at the Mass and the Corps Diplomatique had gone into the Hall of the Throne— It was however near two before the Emperor came in, as there is always a Te Deum on this day as well as a Mass.— Both the Empresses were dress’d with extraordinary magnificence, and an
unusual profusion of diamonds and other precious stones. The Empress Mother especially— The Circle was as short as ever—if any thing, shorter— The Emperor and two Empresses, said very few words to the Ambassador and each of the Ministers. The Emperor noticed that I had at last left off my wig.— I said I had considered his Majesty’s example as a permission, and accordingly followed it— He said it was not so showy, but more convenient to go without it— The Empress asked me about my wife; whether she had recovered from her lying-in, and whether we had now got a comfortable house— The Empress Mother enquired how we had our health in this Country. I said very well, excepting Colds—in which we had at least the advantage of following her example— She said that for a few days she had been seriously unwell; but was now entirely recovered— About two O’Clock I returned home— Mr Smith, was confined to his chamber with a Cold, cough and fever.— Between 8 and 9. in the Evening I went with the Ladies again to the Palace, and attended the Ball given by the Empress-Mother— It was similar to those of the last two years on the same occasion; but the Supper was more magnificent; being served in one of the largest Halls of the Palace— The Empress mother, who does the honours of her own house, was as usual remarkably attentive to her guests, and spoke several times to all the foreign Ministers— Before— At— and after supper— The Emperor asked me whether dancing was not practiced in America— Very much Sir— Well! why do you not dance here?— Because I have given it up. I am too old for dancing. Does your Majesty dance?— No! I say like you, I am too old— The Empress was unwell, and obliged to retire immediately after supper— About half-past-one, the Emperor came up, and said je crois qu’il est tems de sonner la retraite—and with his mother left the Ball-Room— We got home a little after two.

25. We all took bad Colds at the Ball— I slept little and rose soon after six— I took my usual walk before breakfast, and passed the remainder of the day at home— Mr Plincke, my former landlord, sent me his Clerk, with a demand for the payment of 362. Rubles, a fine levied by the master of the Police, and of which payment was required of him, because it was alledged that one of my Servants, a Mooshik who made the fires, and scoured the knives and forks last Winter, had been from New-Year’s day, untill we left the house; without a Passport— And the Clerk brought the contract of lease that I had signed, and opened it to shew that I had stipulated to give notice to the Police, of all the Passports in my family— The Order to pay the money was in Russian, and I could not read or understand it— Plincke’s Clerk understood it no better— I told him that I was utterly ignorant of every thing relating to this demand; but that after Mr Plincke by his own act annulled his Contract of Lease with me, and turned me out of the house, I thought he came with an ill-grace now to hold me to any stipulation contained in it— That I knew nothing of the business and should not pay the money.— The Clerk went his way, and some time afterwards Mr Plincke came himself— He renewed the demand, and said the order, was from the Police, to take his person to prison, unless he paid the money in three days— I repeated to him what I had said to his Clerk, and told him that all I could do was to see and speak to the Minister of the Police upon the subject— I accordingly sent and requested to see the Minister of the Police; and he appointed to-morrow morning at nine O’Clock to see me, at his house. I found upon enquiry afterwards of Waldstein, that this fine had been exacted; not on account of a Passport; but of a ticket, which Servants are required yearly to take out from an Office, called the Address-Comtoir; a paper of which I had never heard before; and which is not even mentioned in my Contract of Lease with Plincke— The Moozhik Tita, whose Passport had been regularly reported to the Police, and who was taken into my service in December last; with such a ticket; either from ignorance or forgetfulness did not take out a new ticket on New-Year’s day; and thereby incurr’d a penalty of two Rubles a day, for which the owner of the house in which he lived is it seems responsible— I read a number more of the Exordium’s of Demosthenes; and nothing else.

26. I called this morning at nine O’Clock on the Minister of the Police, who was gone to the Emperor, but I saw Colonel Gorgoly, who performs the functions of Master of the Police, and by whom the order was issued to Plincke to pay the money for the fine— I explained the Circumstances to him and urged the hardship of the case of levying a fine upon Mr Plincke, for a Circumstance of which he and I were perfectly ignorant— And of which I conceived myself ignorant without blame; having understood that here as well as in other Countries the house of a foreign Minister was not subject to the Jurisdiction of the Police— The Colonel, was extremely complaisant, and polite in form, and assured me that the Police, had the most perfect respect for the mansion of all foreign Ministers, and never presumed to intrude upon them— But that this ticket, was required to be taken out at the Address-Comtoir, by every Russian
serving as a domestic, and must be renewed every year, or whenever the person changed his Master— A capitation tax, of three Rubles for a Mooshik, and proportionally more for servants of a higher rank, was to be paid on taking out this certificate, and to secure the collection of the tax, the owner of the house where every servant lived was responsible upon a penalty of two Rubles a day for any delay in taking it out— That the Police could have no claim whatsoever upon foreign Ministers; but must look to the owners of Houses, whose business it was to make their agreements with foreign Ministers, to indemnify themselves— And that as it was a revenue to the Crown; neither he nor the Minister of Police, could provide any remedy for the case— I shewed him my Contract with Plincke, which I told him Plincke had himself annulled by selling his house to the Crown, and turning me out of doors— I shewed him that even my stipulation in the Contract had reference to nothing but the Passports of my Servants; and made no mention of these Address-Comtoir Certificates— That if the Police thought proper to levy upon Plincke, a fine for a neglect or ignorance of my Servant, of which I knew nothing and could be expected to know nothing, I could only regret the circumstance, but felt my self under no Obligation to pay the money— He said that the Certificate was a thing entirely distinct and separate from the Passport—that as it was not mentioned in my Contract, it was Mr Plincke’s business to have seen to it, and that if I had written him a line stating these Circumstances, I should have had no further trouble in the business; but he requested me to leave the contract and his order with him, and to ask Plincke to call upon him, and he would arrange the matter.— I left the Papers accordingly, and called immediately at the English Magazine, and left word for Mr Plincke to call upon Coll: Gorgoli.— I dined at Count Romanzoff’s, with a diplomatic Company of about sixty persons— The large table— It was in celebration of the Emperor’s birth-day. With the Band of Music, and the Toast in Champagne. I gave the Chevalier de Bray a letter I received this morning for him, in answer to one I had forwarded for him by Mr Anderson, to Gothenburg— I sat next to Count Bussche, who told me that his Landlord, Mr Severin had made a demand of him, on account of a fine levied on him for some irregularity in the Passport of a Mooshik in his service; but he had refused to pay it— Coll: Gorgoli who called upon me before dinner, had told me that Bussche had paid it— He said also that Count St: Julien the Austrian Minister, had been in the same case, and paid to Baron Rall— And also the Portuguese Minister—meaning Navarro— Mr Plincke told me he had been fined for him, and that he must look to him for it hereafter.— I dined very moderately, having felt the whole day a cough coming upon me— I called on my way home, and paid a visit to Madame Bezerra— When I got home, I found that Catherine had taken to her bed, extremely ill with a cough and violent fever. Mrs. Adams and Charles are also troubled with bad Coughs, as well as Mr Smith and almost every Servant in the house. Dr: Galloway was twice here this Evening to see Catherine, who is still more alarmed than ill.— My only reading this day was to finish the Exordium’s of Demosthenes— They are fifty-six in number, and contain many admirable Sentiments— There is in them too much uniformity, and too many repetitions of the same ideas and even expressions— Many of them contain intreaties to be heard, and complaints of being interrupted— Many of them reproaches to the Athenians for their indolence and charges of corruption against other Orators. Several appear to have been prepared for particular occasions, upon which finally the Orator did not speak, or his discourse has not been preserved.

27. We all continue to be afflicted with severe Colds, and Coughs— Catherine is this day somewhat relieved but still confined to her bed. My Cough advances very slowly, and this Evening became very painful at the breast, and internally at the pit of the stomach— Mr Plummer paid me a morning visit, to inform me that the funeral of Mr George Thorndike would be this Evening at six O’Clock— Mr Harris called and invited me to dine with him, and go from his house to the Church; which we accordingly did— Mr Dana, the two Plummers and Mr Williams were at the dinner— Between 6 and 7. we went to the Church where the funeral service was performed by Mr Pitt.— I followed the procession as far as the Bridge, and then returned home.— I read this day the Letters of Demosthenes and Eschines, the last of which pleased me better than the others— Auger says that of all the Greek letters extant, they are in the most perfect epistolary Style— They are indeed so agreeable, that they almost made me feel compunctious in favour of this great rival of Demosthenes— The letter
concerning the young man who personated the river-God Scamander, shews how the Superstitions of the age were sometimes sported with. The Abbé Barthelemi has noticed this transaction, in his Anacharsis.— There are six Letters of Demosthenes, all except one, addressed to the Senate and People of Athens— They are Orations in the form of Epistles— The letters of Eschines are twelve—three of which, addressed to the Senate and People, Auger supposes to be spurious—the rest are private letters, addressed to individuals; the names of whom are not given in most of them.

28. Our house is nearly transformed into a hospital of invalids. We all continue suffering with Colds and Coughs which Doctor Galloway says are epidemical— He advised me this day, to confine myself to the house; with which injunction I very reluctantly complied— There was a second great Ball this Evening, at Count Besborodko’s, to which we were invited— I sent an apology for Mrs Adams, Catherine and myself, who are all confined to the house— Mr Smith went, though still quite unwell himself. I had a morning visit from Mr Montréal— Was unable to write almost entirely, by the pain in my breast— Mr Plincke sent me by his Clerk a letter, informing me that he had this morning paid the money to the Police, for a penalty incurred by me, and that he was informed by the Police-Master what measures to take to enforce the Article of the Contract, by which I was answerable for the Passports of my Servants— I told the Clerk to tell him that there had been no defect in my Servants Passport; that the Police-Master had informed me that the paper in question was entirely a different thing; that I should not pay the money; and he might take his measures; upon which the Clerk went away again— General Tatischeff, also sent me a message, to demand payment for a fine imposed upon him, for the whole time we were at his house in the Country—two Rubles a day on account of the same Mooshik Tita— In my lease from Tatischeff, drawn by himself, and signed by me as drawn, there was no stipulation whatsoever respecting the Servants, their Passports or their Certificates— I sent him word that I was utterly ignorant of this whole affair— That I had expostulated with the Master of the Police, against a fine’s being levied in such a manner upon him; but that I could do nothing further.— There came to me two American Sailors, belonging to the Monticello, Captain Sall, a vessel that has been condemned for coming with false papers— The Captain refuses to pay the men their wages, or to support them— I sent them with a Note to Mr Harris, the only person who has the means of relieving them, or obtaining Justice for them.— I finished reading the second Volume of Auger’s Translation— It concludes with the Oration of Eschines against Timarchus.— This person had engaged himself in conjunction with Demosthenes, as an accuser of Eschines; who retorted upon him, by accusing him of having forfeited by infamous vices the right of speaking in public— Part of this Harangue is omitted by Auger, as containing details of infamy too shocking for the modesty of french ears— It has some very eloquent passages, and particularly one, in which the violent Passions, are said to be the only torturers of the Furies, which Cicero copied into his Oration for Roscius of Ameria— It always struck me there as one of the most beautiful strokes in that Harangue— I did not know that it belonged to Eschines.— There are also in this Discourse many quotations from the Poets— Homer and Euripides— Some of them long, and not much to the purpose— There is not a little invective against Demosthenes, and among others, the reproach that he had been called by the nick-name of Batalus; and that he was foppish and effeminate in his dress.— In this accusation Eschines succeeded— Timarchus was condemned and his name became proverbial for infamy.

29. There was a steady snow almost the whole of this day; and we are still all obliged to keep the house— I had a morning visit from Mr Montréal— The soreness of my breast, and my cough, with the uneasiness and anxiety of mind, occasioned by the illness almost universal of my family, or a culpable indolence which I have not sufficient vigour of mind to overcome, prevented me from writing and reading, as I should have done— I suffer even the arrears of this Journal to accumulate— In the morning I began reading Auger’s third Volume; but only went through the preliminary reflections, and the Summary of the two Orations upon the Crown. In the Evening I read two Sermons in the English preacher—5. and 6. of Vol. 4— On religious sincerity—and on religious toleration of opinions. I attempted to read a few pages of Paley’s Horae Paulinae, which I was obliged to abandon, from heaviness of Spirit, and feverish drowsiness— I was threatened this Evening with a sore throat.— Catherine is slowly recovering, but unable yet to leave her Bed-chamber— Mrs Adams and Charles, in the progress of their Colds, at a stage about the same as my own— Waldstein confined to his bed.

30. Third day of Confinement to the house— I rose after day-light; between 8 and 9. O’Clock— All the family still sick— Catherine, however, left her chamber and sat down with us at dinner; but after sitting a few minutes was obliged to leave the table, and return to her chamber— The infant was quite unwell this Evening— The ladies had an evening visit from Mrs Bentzon— I have now with my cough and Cold, a sore throat. I wrote however during the greatest part of the daylight of this day— Recovered however only a part of my lapses— I read the Oration of Eschines against Ctesiphon; and began the answer of Demosthenes. The Oration of Eschines was a master-piece of Eloquence, and proves him to have been a very superior Man— The question was, whether Ctesiphon had violated the laws by proposing a decree to present a crown of gold to Demosthenes, for his long and faithful services, past and still continuing, and for his virtue and courageous firmness—and that the decree should be proclaimed at the theatre at the feasts of Bacchus, at the time of the new Tragedies. The decree had been adopted by the Senate, and the Cause was to decide whether it should be confirmed by the People— A difficulty occurs which Auger does not entirely remove— How could a decree sanctioned by the Senate and the People, be contrary to the Laws?— It seems extraordinary that the only way to prevent the adoption by the People of a decree already sanctioned by the Senate, should have been by an accusation against the first proposer of the decree—the penalty laid against Ctesiphon is fifty talents—about 30,000 dollars— There is however scarcely any thing about Ctesiphon in the Harangue— The Orator treats him contemptuously; says that Demosthenes had bribed him to propose the decree; and that he and Demosthenes, were each abusive upon the other in relation to this Cause— But he very injudiciously manifests his terror of Demosthenes, by demanding what he must have known would not be granted—first that Ctesiphon should defend himself, and Demosthenes not be allowed to speak for him at-all—or, secondly that Demosthenes should be compelled to follow the same course in the defence, that he had followed in the attack— But this Oration has suggested to me so many reflections, that I must record them elsewhere.

31. I walked out this morning, about an hour before breakfast; and spent the remainder of the day at home. Had morning visits from Mr Montreal and Mr Woodward, and a long one in the Evening from Mr Plummer— Mr Montréal told me that the preliminaries of the Turkish Peace were signed— I was troubled all day with my sore throat, but we are all in the family convalescent— Catherine is almost recovered— I wrote and read less than yesterday, owing to the interruption of visitors—proceeded in the Oration of Demosthenes for the Crown, but did not finish it.

Day. My Resolution of early rising, through the Winter Months has been so constantly traversed by a succession of bad Colds & Coughs, that it has partly failed; I have continued to rise with great irregularity—several mornings not untill broad day-light, which is now not before nine O’Clock— As often however between 5 and 6. and upon the average between 6. and 7.— My practice, as steady as sickness and interruptions would allow, has been to read five Chapters in the German Bible— Write in my Journal. Walk six miles— Breakfast— Read Isocrates, and now Auger’s Demosthenes— Hear Charles read a Fable of La Fontaine—receive visitors, and attend to the domestic affairs of my family. At dusk of Evening, walk another hour—dine at 5. O’Clock— Spend the Evening from seven to eleven with visitors at home, and very rarely abroad— Eleven is my hour for retiring to bed.

I offer to the Supreme disposer of Events at the close of this year the tribute of my fervent gratitude for the blessings his goodness has continued to bestow on my self, and on those who are dearest to me, in its course— In particular for the birth of my daughter— And in imploring a further continuance of his tender mercies upon my Parents and absent Children as well as upon my companion, and children with me, I supplicate chiefly for my self and them the virtues of true piety and integrity, benevolence and Charity; the Christian graces in superaddition to all the Virtues which uninspired Philosophy discovered, and man in his highest glory ever practiced— I pray for his good Spirit to enlighten me in the path of my duty towards himself and towards all my fellow-Creatures in my various relations with them— If it be his will, I pray that before the expiration of another year we may once more restored in safety and health to our Country, and rejoyce in a complete reunion with my Parents, Children, and dearest friends. That this restoration, may be for the greatest good of us-all, and of others— Finally that whatever his Sovereign power and wisdom may destine for us, we may have hearts and minds to receive it with resignation, humility and temperance.
